data.message:
Very good question.
Even if all present encryption can be bypassed, it doesn't mean that tomorrow encryption will be, also, it doesn't mean that all governments or even all government agencies have the technicality to break it.

There's also a very important factor: the cost.
To reach the technology that breaks encryption, it takes too much R&D, that is too much cost (money AND time). It's not bulletproof as well.

Australia has been trying to do tracking for all user actions on the internet. The main issues (besides the obvious privacy ones) were danger of hacking, AND cost of not just storing but inspecting this, and the effect it could have on Internet speed.

Similarly, also in Australia, they passed a rule recently that allows blocking websites (meant to be used for copyright violations). There are 2 ways to apply this, DNS poisoning, which can be bypassed by simply switching to something like Google DNS, or Deep Package Inspection. All pointers suggest ISPs will only use DNS Poisoning, due to high cost and performance effect of Deep Package Inspection.

Regarding certificates, these (I think) can only be manipulated by CAs, which are hard coded into your OS / browser, so, if OS / browser vendors + CAs sell you out, you are doomed. Other dangers are unlikely.
Douglas Crockford is thinking about a new alternative to HTTPS for this very reason :D
